thread.title: Key Labor MP to quit SA politics
thread.title_full: Key Labor MP to quit SA politics

author: Nick Harmsen
title: Key Labor MP to quit SA politics
text:
Labor MP Stephanie Key to quit marginal seat at next SA election By political reporter Nick Harmsen and Claire Campbell Updated February 03, 2017 08:23:30 Map: Ashford 5035 
A veteran Labor MP in South Australia has told supporters she will not be contesting her marginal Adelaide seat at the state election in March next year. 
The Member for Ashford Stephanie Key emailed supporters in the past day to let them know she would not seek preselection for the seat, which is set to be renamed Badcoe after a redistribution changed electoral boundaries. External Link: Weatherill Twitter 
Labor is expected to open preselections for a number of seats as soon as next week. 
Ms Key holds Ashford by a 2 per cent margin, but under the new boundaries Badcoe has a more generous 4.2 per cent notional margin in favour of the ALP. 
The change was one of few bright spots for Labor under the redistribution, which sees the ALP-held seats of Elder, Colton, Mawson and Newland transformed into notional Liberal seats. 
The party has lodged an appeal against the changes and it will be heard by the Supreme Court later in the month. Digance might switch seats 
There has been speculation the current Member for Elder Annabelle Digance may seek a shift to a neighbouring electorate to improve her chances of returning to the Parliament now her seat has become notionally Liberal. 
But Ms Digance told the ABC she did not intend seeking to be a candidate in Badcoe. 
The Liberal Party already has opened nominations for Badcoe, and the Unley Mayor Lachlan Clyne is considered the frontrunner. 
Labor's State Executive will meet next Monday and is expected to open preselections in a host of seats, despite the party challenging new boundaries. 
The preselections move is likely to prompt further retirement announcements from Labor MPs in coming days. 
House of Assembly Speaker Michael Atkinson is widely tipped to retire at the 2018 poll, with Police Minister Peter Malinauskas expected to make a shift from the Legislative Council to run in Mr Atkinson's Labor stronghold of Croydon.
